title: High Spatiotemporal Resolution STEM Imaging at High Temperature
content: Following the remarkable progress of aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), atomic and electronic structures in materials and devices have been well studied. However, the experimental observations are mostly limited to static rather than dynamic in materials. For further understanding of materials properties, it is inevitable to perform in-situ atomic-resolution observation under controlled conditions such as gas/liquid atmosphere and low/high temperature. Since a STEM image is formed by a raster fashion, the temporal resolution is limited to a few seconds [1]. To significantly improve the temporal resolution in STEM, we developed a high-speed scanning probe system with a frame rate of 25 frames per second (fps) for 512Ã—512 pixels, corresponding to 40 ms per frame [2]. In this study, we will present recent progress and applications using high spatiotemporal resolution STEM imaging at high temperature [3, 4].
